prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 140.143 GHz NH3 2-1 IK Tau
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is to search for the para-NH3 nu_2=1, J(K)=2(1)-1(1) transition at 140.143 GHz (Band 4) for the AGB star IK Tauri.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As shown in Figure 4 of the Scientific Justification, the spectral resolution of 2.42 km/s is adequate for the total line width of about 40 km/s. It also allows us to resolve potential features in the line profiles of various interesting lines covered in our 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth, such as NO, N2O, 13CS, H2CS, H2CO, SO2, etc. These lines can provide a validity check to our data and also extra information about the chemistry of O-rich circumstellar envelopes.

For the 140.143-GHz NH3 line, we only aim at a detection survey of the proposed targets in order to keep the time estimate at a reasonable level. So the angular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is employed.
Our previous VLA maps of these targets at about 4-arcsec resolution could only (at best) marginally resolve the NH3-emitting region. So we do not expect the line-emitting region to be larger than that.

As shown in Figure 4 (left panels) of the Scientific Justification, we simulated the line profiles with radiative transfer modelling. In our prediction, the line profile of the 140.143-GHz transition is relatively flat due to coarser angular resolution of 1.0 arcsec. We would therefore integrate the flux over the entire line width of 40 km/s for confirmation of detection. Thus, the integrated S/N ratio is much higher than that over a single channel of 2.4 km/s.
Figure 2 of the Scientific Justification shows the total intensity maps simulated by ALMA OST. The requested RMS is estimated such that, for our weakest source IK Tau, we can still obtain a 6-sigma detection in the total intensity map.

We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth for two reasons. First, we would like to clearly detect the weak continuum emission from the photospheres of our target stars. By that we shall obtain a fiducial point to which the geometry of the detected molecular emission can be referenced to. Second and more importantly, experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 466.244 GHz NH3 0-1 IK Tau
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is to search for the ortho-NH3 nu_2=1, J(K)=0(0)-1(0) transition at 466.244 GHz (Band 8) for the AGB star IK Tauri.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As shown in Figure 4 of the Scientific Justification, the simulated line profiles are much broader than the spectral resolution of 1.25 km/s. This spectral resolution is also able to resolve the possible double-horn feature in some of the simulated profiles (see Figure 4 of Scientific Justification), and is crucial for us to distinguish between different input models.
We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth for two reasons. First, we would like to clearly detect the weak continuum emission from the photospheres of our target stars. By that we shall obtain a fiducial point to which the geometry of the detected molecular emission can be referenced to. Second and more importantly, experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity.
Transitions from NH2, NO2, HNC, N2H+, N15NH+, 30SiO, CO nu=1, SO2, etc. are also covered by our selected basebands. The relatively strong ones, such as 30SiO, can provide a validity check to our data. The detection, and the lack thereof, of a wealth of N-bearing molecules in these basebands could provide further constraints on the nitrogen chemistry in O-rich circumstellar envelopes.

For the 466.244-GHz NH3 line, we would like to estimate the size of vibrationally excited NH3 emission so as to constrain the distribution of hot gas and the pumping mechanism of NH3 molecule. So we need sub-arcsec resolution to acheive the goal. The requested 0.25 arcsec is comparable to the predicted emission size from our radiative transfer modelling.
Our previous VLA maps of these targets at about 4-arcsec resolution could only (at best) marginally resolve the NH3-emitting region. So we do not expect the line-emitting region to be larger than that.

As shown in Figure 4 (right panels) of the Scientific Justification, we simulated the line profiles with radiative transfer modelling. With the, 466.244-GHz transition, we would like to regrid the image cubes to a spectral resolution of 5 km/s. The resultant S/N is higher than that over a single channel of 1.2 km/s by a factor of up to two.
The simulated post-binning images of the channel at line centre are presented in Figure 3 of the Scientific Justification. The requested RMS is estimated such that, for our weakest source IK Tau, we can obtain 12-sigma detection in the 5-km/s channel at the line centre. High S/N is requested to distinguish between different possible physical models (see Figure 4).
At velocities near the horn features (see Figure 4), the S/N level should be higher by about 20%.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Gas-phase ammonia (NH3) has been found to be dramatically overabundant in oxygen-rich circumstellar envelopes (CSEs) of evolved stars as compared to thermo-equilibrium predictions. We propose to observe two transitions of vibrationally excited NH3 (v2=1) at 140.1 and 466.2 GHz toward the O-rich AGB star IK Tau, the red supergiant VY CMa and the protoplanetary nebula OH 231.8+4.2. The data, tracing the hot NH3 gas in the inner CSEs, will be complementary to data from the vibrational ground state, including (1) previously detected low-J rotational lines and (2) observations of radio inversion lines. We will then be able to constrain the inner radius of the NH3 emission via modelling. Knowing the inner radius is important for distinguishing the major formation mechanism of the NH3 molecule. However, this parameter cannot be determined with other telescopes in a reasonable amount of telescope time. Our modelling indicates that both the predicted line profile and brightness temperature of the proposed transitions are very sensitive to the inner radius. Hence these two transitions are the most promising tools to pin down the inner radius of NH3 emission and to understand its formation.
